title: 106_s726
content: The Act may be cited as the "Officer Dale Claxton Bullet Resistant Police Protective Equipment Act of 1999". Congress finds that Officer Dale Claxton of the Cortez, Colorado, Police Department was shot and killed by bullets that passed through the windshield of his police car, highlighting the need for bullet resistant equipment to protect law enforcement officers. Studies show that equipping all officers with such equipment could significantly decrease the number of fatalities in the line of duty. Between 1985 and 1994, 709 law enforcement officers in the United States were feloniously killed, emphasizing the importance of enhancing officer safety. The risk of fatality for law enforcement officers not wearing bullet-resistant equipment is 14 times higher than for those wearing it. Studies show that between 1985 and 1994, bullet-resistant materials saved the lives of over 2,000 officers in the United States. The Executive Committee for Indian Country Law Enforcement Improvements has reported a rise in violent crime in Indian country despite a national decrease, labeling it a "public safety crisis." The purpose of this Act is to save officers' lives by providing them with bullet-resistant equipment and video cameras. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include a Matching Grant Program for Bullet Resistant Equipment under Subpart B. This program aims to provide law enforcement officers with bullet-resistant equipment to save lives. The Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance can grant funds to States, local governments, and Indian tribes to purchase bullet-resistant equipment for law enforcement officers. Grants must be used for buying such equipment and may prioritize jurisdictions with the greatest need based on officer percentage. The Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance can grant funds to States, local governments, and Indian tribes to purchase bullet-resistant equipment for law enforcement officers. Grants prioritize jurisdictions with the greatest need based on officer percentage, violent crime rate, and grant history. In each fiscal year, States receive a minimum of 0.50% of total grants allocated, with exceptions for certain territories. No entity can receive more than 5% of total grants, and a State with its grantees cannot exceed 20%. Matching funds for a program cannot exceed 50% of the costs. Funds from Congress for tribal law enforcement on Indian lands can be used for matching requirements. Half of the funds in this subpart go to local governments with under 100,000 residents. "SEC. 2512. APPLICATIONS." To request a grant under this subpart, the chief executive of a State, unit of local government, or Indian tribe must submit an application to the Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance with required information. The Director will establish regulations within 90 days to implement this section, including application requirements for States, local governments, and Indian tribes. Eligibility includes units of local government receiving funding under the Local Law Enforcement Block Grant program. Units of local government applying for a grant must certify that they have considered using block grant funds for bullet-resistant equipment to be eligible for the grant. Units of local government must certify consideration of using block grant funds for bullet-resistant equipment to be eligible for the grant. SEC. 2513 defines key terms. In this subpart, key terms such as 'equipment', 'State', 'unit of local government', 'Indian tribe', and 'law enforcement officer' are defined. An Indian tribe authorized to engage in prevention, detection, or investigation of criminal law violations or supervise sentenced offenders. "Grant Program For Video Cameras authorized under SEC. 2521." The Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance can grant funds to purchase video cameras for law enforcement vehicles to States, local governments, and Indian tribes. Grants must be used for buying cameras for law enforcement vehicles in the grantee's jurisdiction, with preference given to jurisdictions with the highest need for cameras based on officer percentage. Law enforcement officers without access to video camera-equipped vehicles may receive grants if their department meets certain criteria, such as having a high violent crime rate or not receiving a block grant under the Local Law Enforcement Block Grant program. In each fiscal year, States must allocate a minimum of 0.50 percent of total grants, with exceptions for certain territories. No entity can receive more than 5 percent of total grants, and States with grantees cannot exceed 20 percent. Matching funds for a program under a grant cannot exceed 50 percent of the costs. Funds from Congress for tribal law enforcement on Indian lands can be used for matching requirements. Half of the funds in this subpart go to local governments with under 100,000 residents. "SEC. 2522. APPLICATIONS." To request a grant under this subpart, the chief executive of a State, unit of local government, or Indian tribe must submit an application to the Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance with required information. Regulations will be implemented within 90 days to specify application requirements for States, local governments, and Indian tribes. Eligibility includes units of local government receiving funding under the Local Law Enforcement Block Grant program. Units of local government applying for a grant must certify that they have not used or plan to use block grant funds for purchasing video cameras to be eligible for the grant. Units of local government applying for a grant must certify that they have not used or plan to use block grant funds for purchasing video cameras to be eligible for the grant. SEC. 2523 defines key terms for the grant application process. In this subpart, the term 'Indian tribe' is defined as in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. 'Law enforcement officer' refers to any authorized officer, agent, or employee involved in criminal law enforcement. 'State' includes all 50 states, DC, Puerto Rico, and other territories. 'Unit of local government' encompasses various local governing bodies. Authorization of appropriations for grants under different subparts of part Y is outlined, with specific funding amounts allocated for fiscal years 2000 through 2002. The definition of 'Indian tribe', 'law enforcement officer', 'State', and 'unit of local government' is also provided. SEC. 4. SENSE OF THE CONGRESS. Entities receiving financial assistance should purchase American-made equipment and products. SEC. 5. TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to authorize the Institute to develop new bullet resistant technologies for police equipment and establish standards for testing and operation. The Institute conducts testing and evaluation of bullet resistant technology for police equipment, with priority given to law enforcement partnerships in coordination with High Intensity Drug Trafficking Areas. $3,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2000 through 2002.
